question.p: A laboratory makes 25 repeated measurements on the molecular weight of a protein (in "kilo-Daltons"). The average is 119, and the SD is 15. The lab now wants to estimate the likely size of certain chance errors. You may assume the Gauss model, with no bias. Explain your answers.

ol.li:
The chance error in one measurement is about
[15, 15] 15

The chance error in the average of the measurements is about
$\frac{15}{25}$ $\frac{15}{\sqrt{25}}$ $15$ $15\times \sqrt{25}$ $15\times 25$

question.p: A survey organization takes a simple random sample of 625 households from a city of 80,000 households. On the average, there are 2.30 persons per sample household, and the SD is 1.75. Say whether each of the following statements is true or false.

ol.li:
The SE for the sample average is 0.07.
True False

A 95%-confidence interval for the average household size in the sample is 2.16 to 2.44.
True False

A 95%-confidence interval for the average household size in the city is 2.16 to 2.44.
True False

95% of the households in the city contain between 2.16 and 2.44 persons.
True False

The 95%-confidence level is about right because household size follows the normal curve
True False

The 95%-confidence level is about right because, with 625 draws from the box, the probability histogram for the average of the draws follows the normal curve.
True False

question.p: Laser altimeters can measure elevation to within a few inches, without bias, and with no trend or pattern to the measurements. The Gauss model holds. As part of an experiment, 25 readings were made on the elevation of a mountain peak. These averaged out to 81,411 inches, and their SD was 30 inches.
For each of the following statements, say whether it is true or false, and explain. If the statement is false, change the statement to make it true.

ol.li: $81,411 \pm 12$ inches is a 95%-confidence interval for the average of the 25 readings.
About 95% of the readings were in the range $81,411 \pm 12$ inches.
If another 25 readings are made, there is about a 95% chance that their average will be in the range $81,411 \pm 12$ inches.

12 is the SE, the variability in the average of 25 readings. The variability in the readings is the SD, so about 95% of readings should be in the range $81,411 \pm 30$, assuming the measurements follow the normal curve.
It's true to say that there's a 95% chance that the average of another 25 readings will fall within 2 SE's of the true mean, but 81,411 is not the true mean.

solution.p: Award 2 points for each statement: 1 point for a valid explanation and 1 point for correcting the statement. No points for saying "false" without a valid explanation.

question.p: You want to estimate the average starting salary of Stanford graduates. You call a random sample of 200 students who graduated in the last two years. After collecting the data, you are about to calculate the 95% confidence interval when suddenly you remember (from Stats 60!) that incomes are skewed to the right, whereas a normal curve is necessary for a 95% confidence interval. Was all your work in vain? Explain.

solution.p: No, you're fine. Even if incomes are skewed to the right, when you sample 200 students and take the average, the probability histogram of the average approximately follows the normal curve. To be able to construct a confidence interval, you only need the probability histogram to follow the normal curve.

ul.li: 3 points for realizing that the probability histogram is different from the histogram of the incomes. (The student doesn't have to mention the term "probability histogram" if they clearly understand what's going on.)
3 points for realizing that the probability histogram will be normal with 200 draws, and therefore the confidence interval is valid..

question.p: An airline does a market research survey on travel patterns. It takes a simple random sample of 225 people aged 18 and over in a certain city, and works out the 95%-confidence interval for the average distance they travelled on vacations in the previous year. This was 488 to 592 miles. Say whether each statement below is true or false.

ol.li:
The average of the 225 distances is about
[540, 540] 540 miles.

The SD of the 225 distances is about
[390, 398] 390 miles.

A 95%-confidence interval based on a sample of 450 people will be about half as wide as one based on a sample of 225 people.
True False

question.p: According to the Stanford University Common Data Set 2012-13, 69.46% of Stanford freshmen had an SAT Reading score of at least 700. (The number of freshmen who took the SAT was 1,552.) The Stanford Daily happens to be doing a survey and takes a simple random sample of 100 students. 75 of these students report getting an SAT Reading score $\geq 700$.
Answer the following questions, and explain.

ol.li: What is the SE (exact, not approximate) of the percentage of Stanford students with an SAT Reading score $\geq 700$ in the sample?
True or false: There is about a 95% chance that if the Daily were to take another random sample of 100 students that the percentage with a score $\geq 700$ would be in the range $75\% \pm 2\cdot SE$.

True or false: There is about a 95% chance that if the Daily were to take another random sample of 100 students that the percentage with a score $\geq 700$ would be in the range $69.46\% \pm 2\cdot SE$.

The exact SE is $\frac{\sqrt{.6946(1-.6946)}}{\sqrt{100}}$. (Technically, you should also include the correction factor $\sqrt{\frac{1552-100}{1552-1}}$, but this is optional.) We use 69.46% because that is the percentage of 1's in the box. 75% would be the bootstrap estimate, but there's no need to bootstrap when we know the exact number.

False. This is the confidence interval, but we can't interpret it in this way. The percentage with a score of at least 700 in the sample will follow the normal curve with EV equal to the average of the box, not 75%.
True. The Central Limit Theorem tells us that the average of 100 draws will follow the normal curve with EV 69.46% and this SE.
